cocktails.name: 20Th Century Cocktail
cocktails.instructions: Fill a cocktail shaker with ice. Add 30ml of gin, 20ml of Lillet Blonde, 20ml of Creme de Cacao White and 15ml of lime juice. Shake well and strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with cocoa powder or grated nutmeg.
cocktails.notes: The 20th century is a cocktail created in 1937 by a British bartender named C.A. Tuck, and named in honor of the celebrated 20th Century Limited train which ran between New York City and Chicago from 1902 until 1967. The recipe was first published in 1937 in the Café Royal Cocktail Book by William J Tarling, President of the United Kingdom Bartenders' Guild and head bartender at the Café Royal. ✍️ wikipedia

cocktails.instructions: 1. Fill a highball glass with ice. Add 50ml of whiskey and 150ml of 7Up. Garnish with a lemon wedge.
cocktails.notes: A Seven and Seven or 7 and 7 is a highball cocktail, a mixed alcoholic drink containing Seagram's Seven Crown, which is a blended whiskey, and 7 Up, which is a lemon-lime soft drink. It is typically served with ice. It was one of the most popular drinks in the United States during the 1970s. ✍️wikipedia

cocktails.name: ABC
cocktails.instructions: Pour 15ml of amaretto into a shooter glass. Carefully pour 15ml of Bailey's on top of the amaretto. Helping yourself with a teaspoon, pour 15ml of cognac on top of the Bailey's.
cocktails.notes: The ABC cocktail comes across as rich and comforting, with a soft, dessert-like character. Amaretto brings gentle almond sweetness with a touch of vanilla, while Baileys adds a creamy body layered with cocoa and subtle coffee notes. Cognac rounds everything out, introducing warmth and depth with light fruity and spicy accents. Together, the flavors blend smoothly into a well-balanced, indulgent drink with a silky texture and a warming finish.

cocktails.name: Acapulco
cocktails.instructions: Put some ice cubes into a shaker. Add 50ml of tequila, 50ml of white rum, 75ml of pineapple juice and 50ml of grapefruit juice. Optionally, add a splash of lime juice and 10ml of sugar syrup. Shake well and strain into a hurricane glass.
cocktails.notes: The name of this cocktail refers to the famous coastal city of Acapulco on the Pacific Ocean in Mexico, a country known as the birthplace of tequila and a producer of rum, pineapple, and grapefruit. Acapulco is also where Margarita Sames, an American socialite, is said to have lived and to have created the Margarita cocktail in 1948, another iconic drink built around tequila.

cocktails.name: Adonis
cocktails.instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
cocktails.notes: The Adonis is a sherry and vermouth-based cocktail, with equal parts of both. The cocktail was created in honor of the 1884 musical Adonis after the show reached the milestone of more than 500 shows on Broadway. The Adonis has been described as being a lower alcohol, easier drinking cocktail. ✍️wikipedia

cocktails.name: Adriatique
cocktails.instructions: Fill a cocktail shaker with ice cubes. Add 30ml of amaro, 15ml of Aperol and 30ml of orange juice. Shake and strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with an orange twist.
cocktails.notes: Created by Jackson Cannon, the Adriatique is a vibrant, eye-catching cocktail built around Amaro Montenegro. This amaro brings a rich mix of herbal depth and gentle sweetness, making it both expressive and versatile. Its layered, aromatic character makes it an ideal foundation for a cocktail that’s as flavorful as it is visually striking.

cocktails.name: Agavoni
cocktails.instructions: Fill a rocks glass with ice. Add 30ml of tequila, 30ml of red vermouth and 30ml of Campari and stir. Garnish with an orange slice
cocktails.notes: The Agavoni, sometimes referred to as the Tegroni, is a modern variation of the classic Negroni, distinguished by replacing gin with tequila. It is widely attributed to German mixologist and writer Bastian Heuser.

cocktails.name: Alabama Slammer
cocktails.instructions: Fill a collins glass with ice. Pour 20ml of amaretto, 20ml of Southern Comfort and 20ml of sloe gin. Top with orange juice.
cocktails.notes:
The Alabama Slammer is widely believed to have originated at the University of Alabama in the 1970s, achieving nationwide popularity during the 1980s. It became emblematic of an era often described as the “dark ages” of cocktails, marked by sweet, fruit-forward drinks, and is now regarded as a nostalgic classic.
The exact bar or bartender behind its creation remains uncertain, but the drink’s name and deep crimson hue are closely associated with the university’s Crimson Tide football culture, where it was a favorite at tailgates and campus gatherings. Early references to the recipe appear in the 1971 edition of Playboy Bartender’s Guide by Thomas Mario, indicating that the drink predates its widespread college fame.

cocktails.name: Alexander
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into cocktail shaker filled with ice cubes. Shake and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
cocktails.notes:
The Alexander is a cocktail consisting of cognac, crème de cacao, and cream. It dates from the early 20th century. It was originally made with gin, but the modern version is made with brandy and is called a Brandy Alexander. (✍️ wikipedia)
There are more variations out there like "Alexander's Brother", "Alexander's Sister", "Alexander's Big Brother", but we didn't include the recipes here.
You can replace the Creme de Cacao with Creme de Menthe to get one of the variations if you prefer.

cocktails.name: Alien Brain Hemorrhage
cocktails.instructions: Pour 30ml of peach schnapps into a shooter glass. Add 15ml of Baileys on top and a dash of blue curaçao. Add a few drops of grenadine and drink quickly!
cocktails.notes:
The Alien Brain Hemorrhage is a layered novelty shot that developed from the earlier Brain Hemorrhage shot, emerging in the early to mid-2000s. It became popular for its eerie, “alien” appearance, created by adding Blue Curaçao to the classic combination of peach schnapps, Baileys, and grenadine, resulting in a green-tinted, curdled brain effect. Rooted more in modern bar trends and viral cocktail culture than in a single place of origin, the drink plays on science-fiction imagery while remaining, at its core, a sweet, fruity, and creamy dessert-style shot.
Variation named "Atomic Bomb":
Christos Katsoudas’ Atomic Bomb dates back to the late 1980s in Loutraki, Greece, where it was prepared at the Hotel Kontis Studio 44 bar. While the exact origin of the idea is uncertain, one detail is firmly remembered: the drink was finished with a layer of Cointreau, chosen specifically so it could be ignited. The name Atomic Bomb reflected both its visual impact and its dramatic finish.
For preparation, peach liqueur was kept in the freezer to achieve greater thickness and density. This was followed by a thin layer of blue curaçao and then Baileys Irish Cream. Using a straw, a few drops of grenadine syrup were added from height, creating a distinct vertical red line through the peach layer. The shot was then topped with Cointreau and carefully set alight.
The drink was intended to be consumed quickly through a straw. Caution was essential, as the suction could draw the flame downward along with the liquid.✍️Chris Katsoudas (Lead Developer)

cocktails.name: Almond Old Fashioned
cocktails.instructions: Fill a cocktail shaker with ice. Add 60ml of bourbon, 10ml of Amaretto, 5ml of sugar syrup (ideally demerara or brown sugar syrup) and 1 dash Angostura bitters. Shake and strain into a rocks glass filled with ice. Garnish with an orange twist or toasted almonds.
cocktails.notes:
The Almond Old Fashioned is a contemporary variation on the classic Old Fashioned rather than a historic original. It replaces the traditional orange and cherry elements with almond liqueur—most commonly amaretto, often produced from apricot kernels—while root beer bitters accentuate the drink’s nutty character. The result is a sweeter, almond-forward interpretation that remains faithful to the foundational whiskey, sugar, and bitters structure.

While the twist itself is modern, its lineage reaches back to the earliest definition of a “cocktail” in 1806, with the term Old Fashioned emerging in the 1880s to describe the straightforward whiskey cocktail from which this variation ultimately evolved.

cocktails.name: Americano
cocktails.instructions: Mix the ingredients directly in an old fashioned glass filled with ice cubes. Add a splash of Soda Water. Stir gently.
cocktails.notes: The Americano originated in 1860s Milan at the bar of Gaspare Campari, where it was first served as the Milano-Torino, a simple mix of Campari and sweet vermouth. The later addition of soda water turned it into a lighter long drink that became popular with American visitors, leading to the name Americano. An alternative theory links the name to boxer Primo Carnera in the 1930s. The cocktail also holds literary fame as the first drink ordered by James Bond in Casino Royale.

cocktails.name: AMF - Adios, Motherfucker
cocktails.instructions: Put some ice cubes into a collins glass. Pour 15ml of vodka, 15ml of rum, 15ml of tequila, 15ml of gin and 15ml of blue curaçao. Add 30ml of lemon juice, 30ml of sugar syrup and top with 7Up. Stir gently.
cocktails.notes:
The AMF closely resembles a Long Island Iced Tea, with the main difference being the use of blue curaçao and lemon-lime soda instead of triple sec and cola.
The Adios, Motherfucker (AMF) has no definitive creator, but it is generally believed to have originated in the United States during the late 1980s or early 1990s. Essentially a variation of the Long Island Iced Tea with a few ingredient substitutions, it gained popularity in nightclubs for its high alcohol content, electric-blue color from blue curaçao, and deliberately provocative name. The name reflects the era’s shock-value cocktail trends and humorously suggests that one strong drink might be enough to end the night early.

cocktails.name: Angel Face
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into cocktail shaker filled with ice cubes. Shake and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
cocktails.notes: First recorded in Harry Craddock’s Savoy Cocktail Book (1930), the Angel Face is a Prohibition-era cocktail built on gin, apricot brandy, and Calvados. Though sweet on the nose, it remains firmly spirit-forward and is traditionally shaken and served up in a coupe. Its exact origin is unclear—some link it to French Calvados-based drinks, others to the nickname of an American mobster—making the name a fitting reference to a drink with an innocent look and a serious backbone.

cocktails.name: Aviation
cocktails.instructions: Add all ingredients into a cocktail shaker. Shake with cracked ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
cocktails.notes: The Aviation was created by Hugo Ensslin, head bartender at New York’s Hotel Wallick, and first published in 1916. Its name refers to the drink’s pale blue color, originally achieved with crème de violette. When the violet liqueur was omitted from Harry Craddock’s Savoy Cocktail Book (1930), the cocktail gradually faded from use. The modern revival of crème de violette restored the Aviation to its original form, reestablishing its floral, softly aromatic take on the classic gin sour.

cocktails.name: Barracuda
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into cocktail shaker except the Prosecco, shake well with ice, strain into chilled highball glass filled with ice and top up with Prosecco.
cocktails.notes: The Barracuda was created by Italian bartender Benito Cuppari in the late 1950s–early 1960s aboard Italian cruise liners. After winning a competition in 1966, it gained wider recognition as the signature drink of the SS Michelangelo, famously served in a ceramic pineapple mug promoted by Galliano. Built on rum, Galliano, pineapple juice, and fresh lime, then topped with sparkling wine, the Barracuda balances tropical sweetness with a refined, celebratory finish.

cocktails.name: Batanga
cocktails.instructions: Rim a highball glass with salt. Build over ice, add tequila and Fresh Lime Juice, top up with cola, and stir gently.
cocktails.notes: The Batanga cocktail, a simple mix of tequila, lime, and cola with a salted rim, was invented in 1961 by Don Javier Delgado Corona at his bar, La Capilla (The Chapel), in Tequila, Mexico, named after a stout customer, gaining fame for its unique stir with a large knife that previously chopped limes and salsa ingredients.

cocktails.name: Bee's Knees
cocktails.instructions: Stir honey with lemon and Fresh Orange Juices until it dissolves, add gin and shake with ice. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
cocktails.notes: The Bee’s Knees emerged during American Prohibition in the 1920s as a practical response to harsh, poorly made gin. Honey and fresh lemon juice were used to soften rough edges while adding balance and aroma. The name comes from popular slang of the era meaning “the best,” though its exact origin remains debated, with theories ranging from Paris bartender Frank Meier to American socialite Margaret “Molly” Brown. Its enduring appeal lies in its simplicity—a clean balance of gin, citrus, and honey that proves how minimal ingredients can produce a refined result.

cocktails.name: Bellini
cocktails.instructions: Pour peach puree into the mixing glass with ice, add the Prosecco wine. Stir gently and pour in a chilled flute glass.  Note: PUCCINI - Fresh Mandarin Fresh Orange Juice; ROSSINI - Fresh Strawberry Puree; TINTORETTO - Fresh Pomegranate Juice.
cocktails.notes: The Bellini was created in 1948 by Giuseppe Cipriani, founder of Harry’s Bar in Venice. Made with fresh puréed white peaches topped with Prosecco, it was named after Venetian Renaissance painter Giovanni Bellini, inspired by the drink’s soft pink hue. First served as a seasonal specialty, it became a signature of Harry’s Bar before spreading worldwide as a brunch classic. Its lasting appeal lies in its simplicity and its strong connection to Venetian art, culture, and hospitality.

cocktails.name: Between The Sheets
cocktails.instructions: Add all ingredients into a cocktail shaker. Shake with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
cocktails.notes: Between the Sheets is a robust variation of the Sidecar, distinguished by the addition of rum to an already spirit-forward structure. The cocktail emerged in the 1920s–1930s and is most commonly linked to Harry’s New York Bar in Paris, often attributed to Harry MacElhone, though its exact origin remains debated. Other theories place it in London’s Berkeley Hotel or within Parisian nightlife. Built on cognac, rum, orange liqueur, and fresh lemon juice, it delivers a deceptively balanced profile despite its considerable strength.

cocktails.name: Black Nail
cocktails.instructions: Build over ice and stir gently.
cocktails.notes: The Black Nail is an Irish variation of the Scotch-based Rusty Nail, emerging in New York between the late 1940s and early 1950s, shortly after the introduction of Irish Mist liqueur. Replacing Drambuie with Irish Mist and pairing it with Irish whiskey, the drink offers a softer, sweeter profile with less smoke than its Scottish counterpart. Often mixed in equal parts, it became closely associated with St. Patrick’s Day and reflects the postwar American cocktail scene’s appetite for spirit-forward classics adapted through new liqueurs.

cocktails.name: Black Russian
cocktails.instructions: Pour the ingredients into the old fashioned glass filled with ice cubes. Stir gently.  Note: WHITE RUSSIAN - Float Fresh Cream on the top and stir in slowly.
cocktails.notes: The Black Russian was created in 1949 by Belgian bartender Gustave Tops at Brussels’ Hotel Metropole in honor of Perle Mesta, the U.S. Ambassador to Luxembourg. The drink combines vodka with coffee liqueur, with the name referencing vodka’s association with Russia and the cocktail’s dark color rather than any true Russian origin. Its straightforward, spirit-forward profile made it a postwar favorite, later inspiring the White Russian through the addition of cream.

cocktails.name: Black Velvet
cocktails.instructions: Pour the stout gently into a flute, then carefully top with Champagne to create a layered effect.
cocktails.notes: The Black Velvet was created in 1861 at London’s Brooks’s Club following the death of Prince Albert. Combining stout with Champagne in equal parts, the drink was intended as a liquid expression of mourning, its dark, velvety appearance echoing the black armbands worn by the era’s mourners. Also known as a Bismarck, it strikingly blends aristocratic sparkling wine with working-class stout, resulting in a surprisingly rich and decadent profile despite its somber origins.

cocktails.name: Bloody Mary
cocktails.instructions: Stir gently all the ingredients in a mixing glass with ice, pour into rocks glass. Note: If requested served with ice, pour into highball glass.
cocktails.notes: The Bloody Mary traces its origins to the 1920s at Harry’s New York Bar in Paris, where bartender Fernand “Pete” Petiot first combined vodka with tomato juice. After moving to New York, Petiot refined the recipe at the St. Regis Hotel around 1934 by introducing seasonings such as Worcestershire sauce, black pepper, and Tabasco, shaping the drink as it is known today. The name’s origin remains debated—variously linked to Queen Mary Tudor, a bartender’s acquaintance, or Ernest Hemingway’s circle—but the cocktail’s savory, restorative profile secured its place as a classic “hair of the dog” brunch staple.

cocktails.name: Boulevardier
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into mixing glass with ice cubes. Stir well. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
cocktails.notes: The Boulevardier was created in 1920s Paris by American writer Erskine Gwynne, publisher of the expatriate magazine The Boulevardier. The recipe first appeared in Harry McElhone’s Barflies and Cocktails (1927) and is essentially a Negroni variation, replacing gin with bourbon. Built on bourbon, Campari, and sweet vermouth, the drink reflects the tastes and lifestyle of American expats in Europe during Prohibition. After fading for decades, it has enjoyed a strong revival in the modern craft cocktail movement.

cocktails.name: Bramble
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker except the Crème de Mûre, shake well with ice, strain into chilled old fashioned glass filled with crushed ice, then pour the blackberry liqueur (Crème de Mûre) over the top of the drink, in a circular motion.
cocktails.notes: The Bramble was created in London around 1984 by British bartender Dick Bradsell, inspired by childhood memories of blackberry picking on the Isle of Wight. Conceived as a distinctly British cocktail, it is a modern gin sour built with gin, fresh lemon juice, simple syrup, and blackberry liqueur (crème de mûre). Typically served over crushed ice, the drink balances bright acidity with deep berry sweetness. Emerging during the 1980s cocktail revival, the Bramble remains a clear example of how fresh flavors and restrained structure can produce an elegant modern classic.

cocktails.name: Brandy Alexander
cocktails.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
cocktails.notes: The Brandy Alexander evolved from the original gin-based Alexander cocktail, gaining prominence in the 1920s after brandy replaced gin. Its exact origin is debated—one theory credits bartender Troy Alexander at New York’s Rector’s Café during a promotional event for the fictional character Phoebe Snow, while another links the drink to London and Harry MacElhone around the time of Princess Mary’s 1922 wedding. Rich, creamy, and dessert-like, the Brandy Alexander became a mid-20th-century favorite and remains a classic example of indulgent, spirit-led simplicity.

cocktails.name: Brandy Crusta
cocktails.instructions: Mix together all ingredients with ice cubes in a mixing glass and strain into prepared slim cocktail glass.
cocktails.notes: The Brandy Crusta was created in the 1850s by Joseph Santini in New Orleans and is considered a foundational cocktail in the evolution of the sour style. First documented in Jerry Thomas’s 1862 guide, it is distinguished by its sugared rim—known as the “crusta”—and an oversized citrus peel lining the glass. Built with brandy, orange curaçao, lemon juice, maraschino liqueur, and bitters, the drink balances sharp acidity with aromatic sweetness, with the sugar rim intentionally moderating each sip. Its structure and presentation directly influenced later classics such as the Sidecar.

cocktails.name: Caipirinha
cocktails.instructions: Place lime and sugar into a double old fashioned glass and muddle gently. Fill the glass with cracked ice and add Cachaça. Stir gently to involve ingredients. Note: CAIPIROSKA - Instead of Cachaça use Vodka;
cocktails.notes: The Caipirinha, Brazil’s national cocktail, evolved from a medicinal mixture used in São Paulo around 1918 during the Spanish Flu outbreak. The original preparation combined cachaça with lime, garlic, and honey as a folk remedy. Over time, the garlic and honey were replaced with sugar and ice, transforming it into a refreshing recreational drink. Built on cachaça and fresh lime, the Caipirinha became a defining symbol of Brazilian culture, closely associated with celebration, music, and everyday social life.

cocktails.name: Caipiroska
cocktails.instructions: Muddle lime with sugar in an old fashioned glass, fill with ice, add vodka, and stir well.
cocktails.notes: The Caipiroska emerged in the late 20th century as a vodka-based variation of Brazil’s Caipirinha, replacing cachaça with vodka to suit broader tastes and reflect the growing availability of vodka in South America. Also known as Caipivodka or Caipirodka, it follows the same simple structure of lime and sugar, resulting in a lighter, more neutral profile. Widely adopted across Brazil, Argentina, and Uruguay, the drink became a versatile platform for variations, despite its exact origin remaining unclear.

cocktails.name: Canchanchara
cocktails.instructions: Mix honey with Water and Fresh Lime Juice and spread the mixture on the bottom and sides of the glass. Add cracked ice, and then the rum. End by energetically stirring from bottom to top.
cocktails.notes: The Canchánchara is one of Cuba’s oldest cocktails, dating back to the 19th-century wars of independence. It was prepared by Mambí soldiers using sugarcane spirit (aguardiente), honey, lime, and water as a warming, energizing drink to combat cold and fatigue. Traditionally served in clay cups, its name is believed to reference the leather flasks carried by the fighters. Often regarded as a precursor to classics like the Daiquiri and Mojito, the Canchánchara is now commonly served chilled and remains closely associated with the city of Trinidad.

cocktails.name: Casino
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into cocktails shaker, shake well with ice, strain into chilled rocks glass with ice.
cocktails.notes: he Casino is a classic pre-Prohibition gin cocktail from the early 20th century, valued for its refined, slightly dry, and aromatic profile. Often described as a close relative of the Aviation, it shares a similar gin-forward structure while leaning more decisively toward balance and restraint. Its enduring appeal lies in its elegance and complexity, making it a representative example of early modern cocktail craftsmanship.

cocktails.name: Champagne Cocktail
cocktails.instructions: Place the sugar cube with 2 dashes of Bitters in a large Champagne glass, add the cognac. Pour gently chilled Champagne.
cocktails.notes: The Champagne Cocktail is among the oldest documented cocktails, appearing in the mid-19th century before formal cocktail books became common. It gained wider recognition after being included in Jerry Thomas’s 1862 guide, built simply from Champagne, a sugar cube, and bitters, with cognac added in later interpretations. Elegant and restrained, it became a symbol of celebration and refinement, cemented in popular culture through classic cinema, most notably Casablanca.

cocktails.name: Chilcano
cocktails.instructions: Build in a highball glass filled with ice, add pisco and Fresh Lime Juice, top up with Ginger Ale, and stir gently.
cocktails.notes: The Chilcano originated in Peru in the late 19th century, created by Italian immigrants who adapted their traditional Buongiorno by replacing grappa with local pisco. Combined with ginger ale and lime, the result was a light, refreshing drink well suited to the climate. The name is taken from a traditional fish soup believed to cure hangovers, reflecting the cocktail’s restorative reputation. Simple and easy to prepare, the Chilcano became a staple of Peruvian drinking culture, later evolving with additions such as bitters while retaining its clean, approachable character.

cocktails.name: Clover Club
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into cocktails shaker, shake well with ice, strain into chilled cocktail glass.
cocktails.notes: The Clover Club originated in late 19th-century Philadelphia, named after a private gentlemen’s club that met at the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel. Popular among businessmen, journalists, and writers, the cocktail became a pre-Prohibition favorite, recognized for its silky texture and distinctive pink hue created by raspberry syrup and egg white. Its reputation declined in the 1930s after falling out of fashion, but a renewed appreciation during the early 2000s cocktail renaissance restored the Clover Club as a benchmark for balanced, elegant sour-style drinks.

cocktails.name: Corpse Reviver #2
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into shaker with ice. Shake well and strain in chilled cocktail glass.
cocktails.notes: The Corpse Reviver #2 is a pre-Prohibition gin cocktail popularized by its inclusion in a 1930 cocktail book, where it was famously described as a hangover remedy—albeit one best approached with restraint. Part of a broader family of 19th-century “hair of the dog” drinks, this version combines gin, aromatized wine, orange liqueur, fresh lemon juice, and a light absinthe rinse. Bright and deceptively elegant, it delivers notable strength beneath its refreshing profile, a balance that helped drive its rediscovery during the modern craft cocktail revival.

cocktails.name: Cosmopolitan
cocktails.instructions: Add all ingredients into a cocktail shaker filled with ice. Shake well and strain into a large cocktail glass.
cocktails.notes: The Cosmopolitan evolved from earlier vodka sours such as the Kamikaze, taking shape through several key influences in the late 20th century. In the 1970s, versions incorporating cranberry juice began appearing in the U.S., while the modern standard was refined in New York during the late 1980s–early 1990s with the use of citrus vodka. Its rise to international popularity in the mid-to-late 1990s was fueled by its association with contemporary fashion and nightlife, cementing the Cosmopolitan as a defining modern classic with a clean, balanced, and unmistakably urban character.

cocktails.name: Cuba Libre
cocktails.instructions: Build all ingredients in a highball glass filled with ice.
cocktails.notes: The Cuba Libre, meaning “Free Cuba,” originated in Havana around 1900 in the aftermath of the Spanish–American War. American soldiers combined local rum with newly imported Coca-Cola and fresh lime, raising a toast of “¡Por Cuba Libre!” in celebration of Cuban independence. More than a simple rum and cola, the drink’s name, lime accent, and historical moment give it a distinct identity, transforming a basic highball into a lasting cultural symbol with global reach.

cocktails.name: Daiquiri
cocktails.instructions: In a cocktail shaker add all ingredients. Stir well to dissolve the sugar. Add ice and shake. Strain into chilled cocktail glass.
cocktails.notes: The Daiquiri originated in Cuba around 1898, created by American engineer Jennings Cox, who combined local rum with fresh lime and sugar, naming the drink after the nearby town of Daiquirí. It was later introduced to the United States by naval officer Lucius W. Johnson and further refined in Havana by bartenders such as Constantino Ribalaigua Vert, who helped define its balanced, elegant form. While modern frozen versions became popular much later, the original Daiquiri remains a simple, shaken classic that showcases the purity of rum, citrus, and sugar.

cocktails.name: Dark 'N' Stormy
cocktails.instructions: In a highball glass filled with ice pour the Ginger Beer and top floating with the Rum.
cocktails.notes: The Dark ’n Stormy is Bermuda’s national drink, originating in the early 20th century when British sailors mixed Gosling’s Black Seal Rum with homemade ginger beer. Its name refers to the drink’s dramatic appearance, with dark rum floating over the lighter ginger beer, resembling storm clouds over the sea. Closely tied to Bermudian identity, the name is trademarked by Gosling’s and traditionally refers to the use of their rum and ginger beer. Spicy, refreshing, and deceptively simple, it remains a benchmark rum highball with a strong sense of place.

cocktails.name: Dry Martini
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into mixing glass with ice cubes. Stir well. Strain into chilled martini cocktail glass.
cocktails.notes: The Dry Martini evolved from the sweeter Martinez in the late 19th to early 20th century, shifting from Old Tom gin and sweet vermouth to London Dry gin and dry vermouth. This transition produced a cleaner, more spirit-forward profile that came to define the drink’s identity. Its rise during Prohibition cemented the Martini as both a symbol of rebellion and refined taste, later becoming an icon of modern sophistication. While its exact origin remains debated, the Martini’s defining characteristic—dryness—continued to intensify over time, with contemporary interpretations often using minimal, or even no, vermouth.

cocktails.name: Espresso Martini
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into cocktail shaker, shake well with ice, strain into chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Fernandito
cocktails.instructions: Pour the Fernet Branca into a double old fashioned glass with ice, fill the glass up with Cola. Gently stir.

cocktails.name: French 75
cocktails.instructions: Pour all the ingredients, except Champagne, into a shaker. Shake well and strain into a Champagne flute. Top up with Champagne. Stir gently.

cocktails.name: French Connection
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients directly into an old fashioned glass filled with ice cubes. Stir gently.

cocktails.name: French Martini
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into cocktail shaker, shake well with ice, strain into chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Gimlet
cocktails.instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Gin Fizz
cocktails.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice except Soda Water. Pour into thin tall Tumbler glass , top with a splash Soda Water.  NOTE: Serve without ice.

cocktails.name: Godfather
cocktails.instructions: Build over ice and stir gently.

cocktails.name: Golden Cadillac
cocktails.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Golden Dream
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into shaker filled with ice. Shake briskly for few seconds. Strain into chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Grasshopper
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into shaker filled with ice. Shake briskly for few seconds. Strain into chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Hanky Panky
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into mixing glass with ice cubes. Stir well. Strain into chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Hemingway Special
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a shaker with ice. Shake well and strain into a large cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Horse's Neck
cocktails.instructions: Pour Cognac and Ginger Ale directly into a highball glass with ice cubes. Stir gently. If preferred, add dashes of Angostura Bitter.

cocktails.name: Illegal
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into the shaker. Shake vigorously with ice. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass, or on the rocks in a traditional clay or terracotta mug.

cocktails.name: Irish Coffee
cocktails.instructions: Warm black coffee is poured into a pre-heated Irish coffee glass. Whiskey and at least one teaspoon of sugar is added and stirred until dissolved. Fresh thick chilled cream is carefully poured over the back of a spoon held just above the surface of the coffee. The layer of cream will float on the coffee without mixing. Plain sugar can be replaced with sugar syrup

cocktails.name: John Collins
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients directly into a highball filled with ice. Stir gently. NOTE: Use 'Old Tom' Gin for Tom Collins.

cocktails.name: Jungle Bird
cocktails.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a glass filled with fresh ice.

cocktails.name: Kir
cocktails.instructions: Pour Crème de Cassis into glass, top up with white wine. Note: KIR ROYAL - Use Champagne instead of white wine

cocktails.name: Last Word
cocktails.instructions: Add all ingredients into a cocktail shaker. Shake with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Lemon Drop Martini
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into cocktail shaker, shake well with ice, strain into chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Long Island Ice Tea
cocktails.instructions: Add all ingredients into a highball glass filled with ice. Stir gently.

cocktails.name: Mai-Tai
cocktails.instructions: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice. Shake and pour into a double rocks glass or a highball glass.  The Martinique molasses rum used by Trader Vic was not an Agricole rum but a type of rummy from molasses.

cocktails.name: Manhattan
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into mixing glass with ice cubes. Stir well. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Margarita
cocktails.instructions: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice. Shake and strain into a chilled cocktail glass

cocktails.name: Martinez
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into mixing glass with ice cubes. Stir well. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Mary Pickford
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker, shake well with ice, strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Michelada
cocktails.instructions: Rim a chilled glass with salt. Add Fresh Lime Juice, sauces, and salt, then top up gently with cold beer and stir lightly.

cocktails.name: Mimosa
cocktails.instructions: Pour Fresh Orange Juice into a flute glass and gently pour the Sparkling Wine. Stir gently. Note: Also known as Buck's Fizz.

cocktails.name: Mint Julep
cocktails.instructions: In Julep Stainless Steel Cup gently muddle the mint with sugar and Water. Fill the glass with cracked ice, add the Bourbon and stir well until the cup frosts.

cocktails.name: Mojito
cocktails.instructions: Mix mint sprigs with sugar and Fresh Lime Juice. Add splash of Soda Water and fill the glass with ice. Pour the rum and top with Soda Water. Light stir to involve all ingredients.

cocktails.name: Monkey Gland
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker, shake well with ice, strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Moscow Mule
cocktails.instructions: In a Mule Cup or rocks glass, combine the vodka and Ginger Beer. Add Fresh Lime Juice and gently stir to involve all ingredients.

cocktails.name: Naked And Famous
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into cocktail shaker, shake well with ice, strain into chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Navy Grog
cocktails.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a glass filled with fresh ice.

cocktails.name: Negroni
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients directly into a chilled old fashioned glass filled with ice, Stir gently.

cocktails.name: New York Sour
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into the shaker. Shake vigorously with ice. Strain into a chilled rocks glass filled with ice. Float the wine on top.

cocktails.name: Old Cuban
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into cocktail shaker except the wine, shake well with ice, strain into chilled elegant cocktail glass. Top up with the Sparkling Wine.

cocktails.name: Old Fashioned
cocktails.instructions: Place sugar cube in old fashioned glass and saturate with bitter, add few dashes of Water. Muddle until dissolved. Fill the glass with ice cubes and add whiskey. Stir gently.

cocktails.name: Painkiller
cocktails.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a glass filled with fresh ice.

cocktails.name: Paloma
cocktails.instructions: Pour the tequila into a highball glass, squeeze the Fresh Lime Juice. Add ice and salt, fill up pink grapefruit soda. Stir gently.

cocktails.name: Paper Plane
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into cocktail shaker, shake well with ice, strain into chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Paradise
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into cocktail shaker, shake well with ice, strain into chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Penicillin
cocktails.instructions: Muddle fresh ginger in a shaker and add the remaining ingredients, except for the Islay single malt whiskey. Fill the shaker with ice and shake. Double-strain into a chilled old fashioned glass with ice. Float the single malt whisky on top.

cocktails.name: Pina Colada
cocktails.instructions: Blend all the ingredients with ice in an electric blender, pour into a large glass, and serve with straws.  Note: Historically a few drops of Fresh Lime Juice were added to taste. 4 slices of fresh pineapple can be used instead of juice

cocktails.name: Pisco Sour
cocktails.instructions: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice. Shake and strain into a chilled goblet glass.

cocktails.name: Planter's Punch
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients directly in a small tumbler or a typical terracotta glass. NOTE: Add dilution up to taste, it can be given by Water, ice or fresh juices.

cocktails.name: Porto Flip
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker, shake well with ice, strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Ramos Fizz
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients except Soda Water in a cocktail shaker with ice, Shake for two minutes, double strain in a glass, pour the drink back in the shaker, and hard shake without ice for one minute. Strain into a highball glass, top up with soda. NOTE: The drink was invented by Henry Ramos in 1888, at his bar Meyer's Table d'Hôtel Internationale in New Orleans. The Ramos Fizz was originally shaken for 12 minutes by a crew of 30 bartenders who passed the shaker from one to another.

cocktails.name: Russian Spring Punch
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker except the Sparkling Wine, shake well with ice, strain into a chilled tall tumbler glass filled with ice, and top up with Sparkling Wine.

cocktails.name: Rusty Nail
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients directly into an old fashioned glass filled with ice. Stir gently.

cocktails.name: Sazerac
cocktails.instructions: Rinse a chilled old-fashioned glass with the absinthe, add crushed ice and set it aside. Stir the remaining ingredients over ice in a mixing glass. Discard the ice and any excess absinthe from the prepared glass, strain the mixed drink into the glass.  NOTE: The original recipe changed after the American Civil War, Rye Whiskey substituted Cognac as it became hard to obtain.

cocktails.name: Scorpion
cocktails.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a glass filled with fresh ice.

cocktails.name: Sea Breeze
cocktails.instructions: Build all ingredients in a highball glass filled with ice.

cocktails.name: Sex On The Beach
cocktails.instructions: Build all ingredients in a highball glass filled with ice.

cocktails.name: Shandy
cocktails.instructions: Gently combine equal parts beer and lemonade in a chilled glass. Stir lightly if needed.

cocktails.name: Sherry Cobbler
cocktails.instructions: Build in a glass filled with crushed ice, stir gently, and garnish with seasonal fruit if desired.

cocktails.name: Sidecar
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker, shake well with ice, strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Singapore Sling
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker filled with ice cubes. Shake well. Strain into Hurricane glass.

cocktails.name: Southside
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker, shake well with ice, double-strain into chilled cocktail glass. Note: If Egg White is used shake vigorously.

cocktails.name: Spicy Fifty
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker, shake well with ice, double-strain into chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Spritz
cocktails.instructions: Build all ingredients into a wine glass filled with ice. Stir gently. NOTE: There are other versions of the Spritz that use Campari, Cynar or Select instead of Aperol.

cocktails.name: Stinger
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into mixing glass with ice cubes. Stir well. Strain into chilled martini cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Suffering Bastard
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker except the Ginger Beer, shake well with ice, Pour unstrained into a Collins glass or in the original S. Bastard mug and top up with Ginger Beer.

cocktails.name: Tequila Sunrise
cocktails.instructions: Pour tequila and Fresh Orange Juice directly into highball glass filled with ice cubes. Add the Grenadine Syrup to create chromatic effect (sunrise), do not stir.

cocktails.name: Tipperary
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into mixing glass with ice cubes. Stir well. Strain into chilled martini cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Tom Collins
cocktails.instructions: Shake gin, Fresh Lemon juice, and Simple Syrup with ice. Strain into an ice-filled Collins glass and top up with Soda Water.

cocktails.name: Tommy's Margarita
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker, shake well with ice, strain into a chilled rocks glass filled with ice.

cocktails.name: Trinidad Sour
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker, shake well with ice, strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Tuxedo
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into mixing glass with ice cubes. Stir well. Strain into chilled martini cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Ve.N.To
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into the shaker. Shake vigorously with ice. Strain into a chilled small tumbler glass filled with ice. Notes: If desired Water can be replaced by chamomile infusion in the Honey Mix.

cocktails.name: Vesper
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker filled with ice cubes. Shake and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Vieux Carrè
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into mixing glass with ice cubes. Stir well. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Whiskey Sour
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker filled with ice. Shake well. Strain into cobbler glass. If served on the rocks, strain ingredients into an old fashioned glass filled with ice.  NOTE: If Egg White is used shake little harder to release and incorporate the foam from the Egg White.

cocktails.name: White Lady
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker, shake well with ice, strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: White Russian
cocktails.instructions: Build over ice in an old fashioned glass and stir gently. Float the Fresh Cream on top.

cocktails.name: Yellow Bird
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker, shake well with ice, strain into chilled cocktail glass.

cocktails.name: Zombie
cocktails.instructions: Add all ingredients into an electric blender with 170 grams of cracked ice. With pulse bottom blend for a few seconds. Serve in a tall tumbler glass.  Note: Donn's Mix: 2 parts of fresh yellow grapefruit and 1 part of cinnamon syrup

cocktails.name: Amaretto Sour
cocktails.instructions: Fill a shaker with ice cubes. Add 60ml of amaretto and 30ml of lemon juice. Shake well and pour into a rocks glass. Garnish with a lemon slice. You can use aquafaba or albumin powder instead of egg white.
cocktails.notes:
Dry shake before to create the foam. If you use aquafaba or albumin powder, you need to adjust the quantity.

The Amaretto Sour rose to prominence in the United States during the 1970s, largely popularized by the Italian liqueur brand Disaronno, which promoted a simple combination of amaretto and lemon juice or sour mix. The drink became an emblem of the disco era—approachable, sweet, and easy to drink—though it was often dismissed as lacking sophistication.

While amaretto itself has Italian roots stretching back centuries, the cocktail’s modern identity was shaped by this American marketing push. In recent years, bartenders have revived the Amaretto Sour by incorporating fresh citrus, bourbon, and egg white, transforming it into a richer, more balanced, and complex interpretation of the original.

cocktails.name: Amaro Paloma
cocktails.instructions: Fill a cocktail shaker with ice and add 30ml of tequila, 23ml of Amaro and 2 dashes of Angostura Bitters. Add 30ml of grapefruit juice, 10ml of lime juice and 5ml of sugar syrup. Shake well and strain into a rocks glass with ice. Top with a splash of soda water. Garnish with a slice of grapefruit.
cocktails.notes: The Amaro Paloma is a contemporary variation rather than a traditional cocktail with a long-standing history. It reimagines the classic Mexican Paloma—typically made with tequila, grapefruit soda, lime, and a pinch of salt—by incorporating an Italian herbal liqueur such as Amaro Montenegro. The addition of amaro introduces a bittersweet, herbal complexity that deepens the drink while preserving the Paloma’s bright, refreshing character.

cocktails.name: Ambassador
cocktails.instructions: Put some ice into a rocks glass. Add 30ml of tequila blanco, 50ml of orange juice and 15ml of sugar syrup. Stir well and garnish with an orange slice.

cocktails.name: Anaconda
cocktails.instructions: Fill a shaker with ice and pour the ingredients. Shake well and strain into a shot glass.
cocktails.notes:
It is best to create more than 3 at a time.
The "Anaconda" cocktail does not have a single, widely recognized historical origin like classic drinks such as the Margarita or Old Fashioned. Instead, the name has been used by various people and establishments to describe different, unrelated cocktail recipes.

cocktails.name: Angel's Kiss
cocktails.instructions: Pour 15ml of crème de cacao white into a shooter glass. Carefully pour 10ml of sloe gin on top of the crème de cacao and 10ml of brandy on top of the gin. Carefully top with 10ml of cream or whipped cream.
cocktails.notes: Angel’s Kiss is a classic layered cocktail that rose to popularity during Prohibition, built around sweet liqueurs such as crème de cacao, often combined with brandy or cream. Designed for visual impact, the careful layering creates its signature “kiss” effect. Its exact origin remains unclear—sometimes linked to Detroit’s underworld, other times viewed simply as a descriptive dessert drink. Over time, the recipe has evolved, with variations appearing across eras and regions, including modern reinterpretations using unexpected spirits like mezcal.

cocktails.name: Angel's Tit
cocktails.instructions: Pour 15ml of crème de cacao white into a chilled cocktail glass. Carefully add 30ml of maraschino liqueur on top. Top with 30ml of whipped cream. Garnish with a maraschino cherry.
cocktails.notes: Angel’s Tit (also known as Angel’s Tip) is a classic layered dessert cocktail that became popular during the Prohibition era of the 1920s–1930s. It belongs to the pousse-café family, defined by carefully stacked liqueurs separated by differences in density rather than mixing. Typically rich and indulgent, the drink is as much about visual presentation as flavor, with precise layering being essential to its identity. Despite its provocative name, it remains a showcase of classic technique and period styling rather than excess.

cocktails.name: Apple Cart
cocktails.instructions: Combine 45ml of calvados, 30ml of triple sec and 30ml of lemon juice in a cocktail shaker with ice. Shake well and strain into a Martini glass. Garnish with an apple wedge.
cocktails.notes: Apple Cart is a variation of the classic Sidecar, replacing cognac with Calvados to highlight a brighter, more pronounced apple character. Built around apple brandy, orange liqueur, and fresh lemon juice, it retains the Sidecar’s balanced structure while shifting the flavor profile toward orchard fruit. Its history follows the Sidecar’s uncertain post–World War I origins in Paris or London, with Apple Cart emerging later as a seasonal, autumn-leaning adaptation. Modern interpretations sometimes push the apple note further with ingredients such as cider or apple schnapps.

cocktails.name: Black & Tan
cocktails.instructions: Layer stout over ale
cocktails.notes: Black and Tan is a layered beer drink combining pale ale and stout, rooted in long-standing English traditions of blending beers. The name appears in print from the late 19th century, but it carries sensitive historical associations in Ireland due to its link with a British paramilitary force active during the Irish War of Independence. For this reason, the drink is commonly referred to as a “Half and Half” in Ireland. While popular in the United States for its visual contrast and complementary flavors, the name remains culturally charged, making terminology an important consideration depending on context and location.

cocktails.name: Boilermaker
cocktails.instructions: Pour the whiskey in the beer
cocktails.notes: The Boilermaker is a simple combination of beer and a shot of whiskey, with roots in 19th-century American industrial culture. It is commonly linked to boilermakers and miners who sought a strong, no-nonsense drink after long hours of physical labor. The drink is often associated with the 1890s in Butte, Montana, where it was sometimes known as a “Sean O’Farrell.” Over time, it became a popular, affordable after-work choice, traditionally served either with the beer and whiskey side by side or with the shot dropped into the beer in a style known as a “depth charge.”

cocktails.name: Flaming Dr. Pepper
cocktails.instructions: Pour the amaretto in a shot glass. Add slowly on top the overproof rum to create a layer. Light the rum and quickly drop it in the pint glass with the half pint beer. Make sure there are no flames. Drink it.
cocktails.notes: Use caution as the flames might not be visible.

cocktails.name: Flaming Engineer
cocktails.instructions: Pour the beer into the beer mug. Add the amaretto and the whiskey. Fill with orange juice.
cocktails.notes: Also known as a Billy and Dr. Boil My Gladiator

cocktails.name: Irish Car Bomb
cocktails.instructions: Pour Guinness into the pint glass. Pour Baileys and Jameson into the shot glass. Pour the shot into the beer. This recipe is here only as a reference. Read the notes.
cocktails.notes: When the Baileys mixes with the beer it will begin to curdle very quickly, requiring the drink to be consumed promptly. It is sometimes considered improper to order this drink in an Irish establishment. Some United States bars refuse to sell it, and it is not sold in Ireland, where it has been suggested that it is the equivalent of ordering a "9/11 ice-cream sundae."

cocktails.name: American Revolution
cocktails.instructions: Muddle orange peel in 25ml of the gin. Add the remainder of the gin, the bourbon, the bitters, and ice to the glass. Stir for 30 seconds. Strain into Old Fashioned glass and fill glass with ice. Garnish with sour cherries.
cocktails.notes:
The American Revolution is a modern, spirit-forward cocktail built in the style of an Old Fashioned. It uniquely combines gin and bourbon, balancing botanical dryness with warm vanilla and oak notes. Angostura bitters add spice and structure, while the orange peel enhances citrus oils and aroma. Sour cherries provide a subtle sweetness and a classic finish. The drink is bold, aromatic, and refined, designed to be sipped slowly.
If you search the internet you might find different recipes. They are not wrong. There are more recipes out there with the same name. ✍️Bar Mix&Wiz

cocktails.name: Eccentric Elmer
cocktails.instructions: Fill a cocktail shaker halfway with ice. Add the bourbon, Cointreau, bitters, and the cranberry juice to the shaker. Shake well. Put a few ice cubes into an old-fashioned glass. Strain the cocktail into the glass. Garnish with a lime wedge.
cocktails.notes:
Eccentric Elmer is a smooth, bourbon-forward cocktail with balanced sweetness and a subtle bitter edge. Cranberry cocktail is recommended rather than pure cranberry juice, as it provides the necessary sweetness and body. If only cranberry juice is available, add one tablespoon of superfine sugar to the shaker to restore balance and achieve a comparable flavor profile.
Eccentric Elmer is a modern bourbon cocktail known for its smooth structure, balancing gentle cranberry sweetness with a subtle bitter edge. Unlike many historical classics, it has no firmly documented origin, but is commonly understood as a contemporary creation inspired by the character and legacy of Elmer T. Lee. The recipe gained wider recognition through modern bartending references such as Wikibooks, valued for its approachable, well-rounded profile that highlights bourbon without overwhelming it.

cocktails.name: Nixon
cocktails.instructions: Stir and serve on the rocks, garnished with a slice of fresh peach.
cocktails.notes: The Nixon cocktail was created by Joe Gilmore, Head Barman of the American Bar at the Savoy Hotel in London, to commemorate U.S. President Richard Nixon’s visit to Britain in 1969. The drink was prepared at the Savoy’s American Bar and then delivered to Claridge’s, where Nixon was staying.

cocktails.name: Bronx Cocktail
cocktails.instructions: Pour all ingredients into shaker with ice cubes, shake well. Strain into chilled martini glass.
cocktails.notes: The Bronx Cocktail was created around 1906 at New York’s Waldorf-Astoria by bartender Johnny Solon and is often cited as one of the first cocktails to incorporate fresh orange juice. Named after the nearby Bronx Zoo, it quickly rose to prominence before Prohibition as a lighter, fruit-forward alternative to the Martini. Built on gin with both dry and sweet vermouth, the addition of orange juice softens the structure while preserving balance, marking an early shift toward fresher citrus-driven cocktails in classic bar culture.

cocktails.name: Gin Rickey
cocktails.instructions: Build in a highball glass with ice.
cocktails.notes: The Rickey originated in the 1880s at Shoomaker’s Bar in Washington, D.C. It was named after Colonel Joe Rickey, a Democratic lobbyist who favored his daily drink unsweetened and originally made with bourbon. About a decade later, the gin-based version rose to prominence and was later immortalized in The Great Gatsby by F. Scott Fitzgerald. In 2011, the Rickey was officially recognized as Washington, D.C.’s native cocktail.

cocktails.name: Lady Killer
cocktails.instructions: Pour all the ingredients into a shaker with ice. Cut the fresh passion fruit in half and add all the seeds and flesh into the shaker. Shake well and fine strain in a chilled old fashioned glass.

cocktails.name: Saketini
cocktails.instructions: Stir gin, sake and ice in a mixing glass. Strain into a chilled martini glass. Garnish with a green olive.
cocktails.notes: The Cocktail Detective (2015) traces the drink’s origin to chef Matsuda, who is said to have created it in Queens during the 1964 World’s Fair, with the recipe resurfacing decades later in the 1990s. Ahead of the broader martini revival in the early 2000s, sake began to appear more frequently as a cocktail base, alongside an expanding use of the term “martini” to describe a wide range of mixed drinks. While some traditionalists argue that the saketini undermines the classic gin-and-vermouth formula, others have embraced it as a legitimate evolution. Mixologist Lucy Brennan has been a vocal supporter, developing numerous sake-based cocktails, and Benihana founder Hiroaki Aoki has similarly defended the concept, noting that if a sake cocktail is enjoyable, tradition should not hinder innovation. If you search the internet you will find many variations.

cocktails.name: G Sling
cocktails.instructions: Shake with ice and server in an old fashioned glass. Garnish with lime slice and a flower.
cocktails.notes: This recipe is a creation of the incredibly talented Lucy Brennan.

cocktails.name: Pear Flower
cocktails.instructions: Shake ingredients with ice and strain in a highball with ice. Garnish with a flower.
cocktails.notes: This recipe is a creation of the incredibly talented Lucy Brennan.

cocktails.name: Dragon's Milk
cocktails.instructions: Shake ingredients with ice and strain in a highball with ice. Garnish with a flower.
cocktails.notes: Dragon’s Milk is a modern sake cocktail built around Nigori (unfiltered) sake, prized for its naturally creamy texture and gentle sweetness. Often associated with styles such as Momokawa Nigori, the drink leans into tropical, dessert-like flavors while remaining soft and approachable. Its appeal lies in texture as much as taste, showcasing Nigori sake as a versatile base for creamy, contemporary cocktail expressions.

cocktails.name: Three Dollar Shoes
cocktails.instructions: Shake all ingredients. Strain in an old fashioned with ice. Garnish as you see fit.
cocktails.notes:
The Three Dollar Shoes cocktail was created in Albuquerque, New Mexico, on 21 July 2006 as a strong yet sweet pre-club drink, intended to be enjoyed before a night of salsa dancing. The original version combined Seagram’s with margarita mixer, later enhanced with Bombay Sapphire to increase its alcoholic strength. Inspired by a pair of pink high-heel shoes recently purchased for three dollars by one of the creators, grenadine was added to give the drink its distinctive pink hue.
True to its informal origins, the cocktail was initially served in a plastic water bottle for convenience and portability. In the same spirit, it is best served from a large, inexpensive plastic bottle whenever possible, although a standard drink mixer may also be used.

cocktails.name: Blue Hawaiian
cocktails.instructions:
On the rocks: Shake all ingredients with ice. Strain in a highball with crushed ice. Garnish with a pineapple wedge.
Frozen: Blend all ingredients with ice in an electric mixer. Pour it in a hurricane glass. Garnish with a pineapple wedge.
cocktails.notes: The Blue Hawaii was created in 1957 by bartender Harry Yee at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in Waikiki for a Bols liqueur sales representative. Built with blue curaçao, rum, vodka, and a sweet-and-sour base, the drink is light, citrus-forward, and visually striking. Its name was inspired by the song featured in the 1937 film Waikiki Wedding, not the later Elvis movie often associated with it. A richer variation, the Blue Hawaiian, adds coconut cream, while the original remains brighter and more refreshing in character.

cocktails.name: Flat Liner
cocktails.instructions: Add the Sambuca in a shot glass. Add a few drops of Tabasco. Slowly add the tequila.
cocktails.notes: The Flat Liner is a layered shooter served in a shot glass, distinguished by a thin line of Tabasco sauce separating two layers of spirits. In Estonia, the drink is also known as Millimalikas, which translates to “Jellyfish” in Estonian.

cocktails.name: Eucazini
cocktails.instructions: Shake all the ingredients with ice. Strain in a chilled martini glass. Garnish with an orange wedge.
cocktails.notes: The Eukazini cocktail was created on 17 December 2006 by bartender Kaz Santiago in collaboration with customer Euan Morse at Ryan’s Bar.

cocktails.name: Polish Martini
cocktails.instructions: Zubrowka and Krupnik should be in the freezer. Shake all ingredients with crushes ice. Strain in a chilled martini glass. No garnish.
cocktails.notes: The Polish Martini is a sweet, apple-forward cocktail made with bison grass vodka, honey liqueur, and apple juice. Rather than resembling a classic dry martini, it draws inspiration from a traditional Polish pairing of apple juice and Żubrówka (bison grass vodka), commonly known as a Szarlotka or Tatanka.

cocktails.name: Rob Roy
cocktails.instructions: Add ice in a mixing glass. Add all the ingredients and stir. Strain into a chilled martini glass. Garnish with a maraschino cherry.
cocktails.notes: The Rob Roy is a Scotch whisky–based variation of the Manhattan, believed to have originated around 1894 at the Waldorf Astoria in New York City. The cocktail was named after the popular operetta Rob Roy, which celebrated the Scottish folk hero Rob Roy MacGregor. To reflect the Scottish theme, bartenders replaced American whiskey with Scotch, creating what is often described as a classic “Scotch Manhattan.”

cocktails.name: Bentley
cocktails.instructions: Put ice cubes into a mixing glass, pour 45ml of calvados and 45ml of Dubonnet, optionally add 2 dashes of Peychaud's bitters or orange bitters, stir well and strain into a chilled Martini or rocks glass, garnish with an orange peel.
cocktails.notes: The Bentley is a classic cocktail of the late 1920s, closely associated with British motoring culture and the legendary “Bentley Boys.” The drink is traditionally linked to Bentley’s victory at the 1927 24 Hours of Le Mans, celebrating the era’s wealthy, thrill-seeking racing drivers. It was popularized by Harry Craddock at the American Bar of London’s Savoy Hotel and later documented in The Savoy Cocktail Book (1930). According to legend, the cocktail was improvised during post-race celebrations using the available Calvados and Dubonnet, resulting in a distinctive, spirit-forward profile with pronounced apple and fortified wine notes.

cocktails.name: Bijou
cocktails.instructions: Add ice to a mixing glass and measure in 50ml gin, 30ml sweet vermouth and 20ml Chartreuse, season with a dash of orange bitters and stir smoothly for about 20 seconds, then strain into a well-chilled cocktail glass and finish with a lemon peel if desired.
cocktails.notes: The Bijou is a pre-Prohibition classic dating back to the 1890s, credited to renowned bartender Harry Johnson. Conceived as a “triple” cocktail, it brings together gin, sweet vermouth, and green herbal liqueur in equal importance. Rich, aromatic, and complex, the Bijou showcases layered botanicals and bitterness, standing as an early example of balance through intensity rather than restraint.

cocktails.name: Apple Sunrise
cocktails.instructions: Fill a chilled Collins glass with ice, add 10ml of lemon juice followed by 15ml crème de cassis and 50ml calvados, then gently top with about 100ml of orange juice, give a light stir to keep the layered look, and finish with an apple slice garnish.
cocktails.notes: Apple Sunrise is a bright, fruit-forward variation of the Tequila Sunrise, replacing tequila with apple brandy—most commonly Calvados—for a softer, orchard-driven profile. Crème de cassis is often used to create the drink’s signature color gradient while adding subtle berry depth. The cocktail is commonly attributed to Charles Schumann, who is believed to have created it in Munich around 1980. Elegant and approachable, it adapts a familiar structure into a more aromatic, European-style expression.

cocktails.name: Appletini
cocktails.instructions: Chill a mixing glass with ice, pour in 40ml vodka along with 15ml apple schnapps and 15ml Cointreau, stir until well chilled, strain into a cold cocktail glass, and finish with a fresh slice of apple.
cocktails.notes: The Appletini originated in 1997 at Lola’s in West Hollywood, created by bartender Adam Karsten—a playfully literal origin reflected in its early name, “Adam’s Apple Martini.” Built with vodka and sour apple liqueur, it was initially developed to move excess inventory, but quickly caught on for its vivid green color and candy-like, Jolly Rancher profile. A defining drink of the late 1990s, the Appletini evolved from earlier vodka–apple juice mixes and has since inspired modern reinterpretations that favor fresher apple elements and tighter balance.

cocktails.name: Asian Hooker
cocktails.instructions: Pack a hurricane or Collins glass with ice, add 10ml overproof rum, 45ml Malibu coconut rum and 15ml melon liqueur, then top with roughly equal amounts of pineapple juice and 7Up or soda water (about 80ml total), and give it a good stir to combine.
cocktails.notes: Asian Hooker is a modern, high-alcohol cocktail known for its bright green color and sweet-and-sour, tropical profile. It belongs to a broader family of contemporary “Hooker”-style drinks and is typically built around melon liqueur paired with high-proof rum. Lacking deep historical roots, the cocktail emerged from late-20th-century party and pop-culture drink trends, favoring bold flavor, visual impact, and intensity over classic balance. Its identity is defined more by style and presentation than by tradition, placing it firmly in the modern, nightlife-driven cocktail category.

cocktails.name: B-52
cocktails.instructions: Pour 20ml of Kahlúa into a shooter glass, gently layer Baileys over it and then float Grand Marnier or another high-proof orange liqueur on top, ignite the surface and consume while aflame using a long straw.
cocktails.notes: The B-52 emerged in the 1970s, most commonly credited to bartender Peter Fich at the Banff Springs Hotel around 1977. The name is said to reference the band rather than the military aircraft, though alternative origin stories place the drink elsewhere. Built as a layered shot of coffee liqueur, Irish cream, and orange liqueur, the B-52 is defined by its visual precision, achieved by carefully floating each component according to density using a bar spoon. Its striking presentation helped secure its popularity in late-20th-century bar culture.

cocktails.name: B-55
cocktails.instructions: Start by adding 20ml of Kahlúa or another coffee liqueur to a shooter glass, carefully layer 20ml of Baileys on top, then gently float 15ml of absinthe as the final layer, light the drink and consume while flaming using a long straw.
cocktails.notes: The B-55 is a layered shooter developed as a more intense variation of the classic B-52, emerging after the original’s popularity in the late 20th century. Part of the broader “B-50” family of shots, it follows the same layered structure but replaces the orange liqueur with high-proof absinthe, introducing a sharper, herbal edge. While the B-52 is commonly credited to Peter Fich at the Banff Springs Hotel in 1977, the B-55 represents a later evolution, designed to amplify strength and complexity while retaining the visual precision of layered shooters.

cocktails.name: BMW
cocktails.instructions: Fill a rocks glass with ice, pour in equal parts of Baileys, Malibu and whiskey at 45ml each, and stir thoroughly until well combined and chilled.
cocktails.notes: The BMW cocktail has no firmly documented historical origin, with its name derived directly from its core ingredients: Baileys Irish Cream, Malibu coconut rum, and whiskey. Typically prepared as a layered or lightly mixed drink, it delivers a creamy, tropical sweetness balanced by a boozy backbone. Rather than emerging from a specific era or bartender, the BMW developed as a modern, dessert-style shooter, valued for its simplicity, recognizability, and crowd-pleasing profile.

cocktails.name: Baby Guinness
cocktails.instructions: Add 30ml of coffee liqueur to a shooter glass, then gently layer 15ml of Irish cream liqueur over the top.
cocktails.notes: The Baby Guinness is a popular layered shot designed to resemble a miniature pint of stout. It is widely believed to have originated in Ireland in the late 1980s, often linked to Dublin’s Waxies Dargle, where it was reportedly served to new fathers celebrating the birth of a child—giving the drink its name. Made with coffee liqueur as the dark base and Irish cream floated on top to mimic the foam, it contains no actual Guinness. Its visual novelty, simplicity, and celebratory association helped establish it as a modern party staple.

cocktails.name: Bahama Mama
cocktails.instructions: Add cracked ice to a shaker, pour in 45ml rum, 30ml Malibu coconut rum and 15ml cherry brandy, then add 15ml lemon juice, 60ml orange juice, 60ml pineapple juice and 10ml grenadine, shake vigorously until well chilled, strain into a cold hurricane glass, and finish with an orange slice garnish.
cocktails.notes: The Bahama Mama is a classic tropical cocktail closely associated with mid-20th-century Caribbean vacation culture. Its exact origins are unclear and widely debated, with theories ranging from early Bahamian rum traditions to influences from Prohibition-era rum running and calypso music. Though often grouped with 1950s–60s tiki-style drinks, the Bahama Mama reflects a broader tropical lineage, defined more by escapism and flavor than by a single documented moment of creation.

ingredients.name: 100% Agave Tequila
ingredients.notes: 100% agave tequila is a premium spirit distilled exclusively from the fermented sugars of the Blue Weber agave plant, containing no added sugar from other sources

ingredients.name: 100% Agave Tequila Reposado
ingredients.notes: Expect bright, earthy flavors with subtle notes of citrus and fresh herbs. Ideal for sipping neat or elevating cocktails. Reposado tequila, aged for at least two months and up to a year in oak barrels, develops a smooth, mellow character with added depth and warmth.
